quote: Prick not your finger as you pluck it off, lest, bleeding, you do paint the white rose red, and fall on my side so against your will.

quote: Must not hear thee. Fare thee well, kind maid. Thy pains, not used, must by thyself be paid.

quote: Would it were hell pains for thy sake, and my poor doing eternal; for doing am past, as will by thee in what motion age will give me leave.

quote: Brought you this letter, gentlemen? Ay, madam, and for the contents' sake are sorry for our pains.

quote: Now, my co-mates and brothers in exile, hath not old custom made this life more sweet than that of painted pomp?

No, my complete master, but to jig off a tune at the tongue's end, canary to it with your feet, humor it with turning up your eyelids, sigh a note and sing a note, sometimes through the throat as if you swallowed love with singing love, sometimes through the nose as if you snuffed up love by smelling love; with your hat penthouse-like o'er the shop of your eyes, with your arms crossed on your thin-belly doublet like a rabbit on a spit; or your hands in your pocket like a man after the old painting; and keep not too long in one tune, but a snip and away.

quote: Gentlemen and friends, thank you for your pains.

quote: That's because the one is painted, and the other out of all count.
play: (The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 0, Scene 22)

quote: How painted? And how out of count? Marry, sir, so painted to make her fair, that no man counts of her beauty.

quote: Perchance you think too much of so much pains? No, madam.

quote: This minion stood upon her chastity, upon her nuptial vow, her loyalty, and with that painted hope braves your mightiness; and shall she carry this unto her grave?

Never more must we behold those comforts, never see the hardy youths strive for the games of honor, hung with the painted favors of their ladies, like tall ships under sail; then start amongst 'em and as an east wind leave 'em all behind us, like lazy clouds, whilst Palamon and Arcite, even in the wagging of a wanton leg, outstripped the people's praises, won the garlands ere they have time to wish 'em ours.
It is the very emblem of a maid. For when the west wind courts her gently, how modestly she blows and paints the sun with her chaste blushes!
